    Advances in Cyclic Nucleotide Phosphodiesterase-Targeted PET Imaging and Drug Discovery

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterases (PDEs) control the intracellular concentrations of cAMP and cGMP in virtually all mammalian cells. Accordingly, the PDE family regulates a myriad of physiological functions, including cell proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis, gene expression, central nervous system function, and muscle contraction. Along this line, dysfunction of PDEs has been implicated in neurodegenerative disorders, coronary artery diseases, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and cancer development. To date, 11 PDE families have been identified; however, their distinct roles in the various pathologies are largely unexplored and subject to contemporary research efforts. Indeed, there is growing interest for the development of isoform-selective PDE inhibitors as potential therapeutic agents. Similarly, the evolving knowledge on the various PDE isoforms has channeled the identification of new PET probes, allowing isoform-selective imaging. This review highlights recent advances in PDE-targeted PET tracer development, thereby focusing on efforts to assess disease-related PDE pathophysiology and to support isoform-selective drug discovery.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterases (PDEs) constitute a superfamily of enzymes that catalyze the degradation of the second messengers, cyclic adenosine 3â²,5â²-monophosphate (cAMP) and cyclic guanosine 3â²,5â²-monophosphate (cGMP). Notably, cyclic nucleotide PDEs can be found in virtually all mammalian cells, where they modulate numerous downstream signaling processes by controlling the intracellular content of cyclic nucleotides and creating individual pockets of cyclic nucleotide signaling.(1) Indeed, PDEs mediate a variety of physiological processes, including ion channel function, muscle contraction, central nervous system (CNS) function, apoptosis, glycogenolysis, and gluconeogenesis. Dysfunction of PDEs, however, has been implicated in various neurological and cardiovascular diseases, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and cancer development.(2â4) While ongoing research continues to tackle the plethora of unanswered questions regarding the roles of different PDE isoforms in related pathologies, there is a general consensus that the pharmacological inhibition of PDEs provides a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of various human diseases.(1,4â13) Further, given the broad therapeutic implications, it is not surprising that PDEs have been deemed important targets for translational molecular imaging by positron emission tomography (PET).
    PET is a noninvasive imaging technique that allows visualization and quantification of biochemical processes in vivo. These processes include enzymatic and transporter activity, protein biosynthesis, as well as ligand binding to specific receptors or enzymes at the molecular and cellular levels. PET has not only been widely applied for disease diagnosis in oncology, neurology, and cardiology,(14â16) but has also been used to facilitate drug discovery.(17,18) In preclinical and clinical drug development, PET provides critical information about target engagement and occupancy of a drug candidate at a given dose regimen. Further, PET can be used for the assessment of compound selectivity in vivo. Although research on PDEs has been carried out for decades, only a few PET radioligands, mainly focused on the subtypes of PDE2, PDE4, PDE5, PDE7, and PDE10, were developed for PDE-targeted PET imaging.(19â22) Nevertheless, these probes have enabled real-time PDE quantification, thus significantly contributing to our contemporary understanding of PDE-related pathophysiology. Meanwhile, the development of radioligands for imaging PDEs has forged new paths for the evaluation of novel PDE inhibitors. To date, a number of PET radioligands, derived from clinically used PDE inhibitors, have been reported.
    The growing interest in the development of isoform-selective PDE inhibitors as potential therapeutic agents has triggered a wave of enthusiasm and prompted calls for new PET probes that allow isoform-selective imaging. This review highlights recent advances in PDE-targeted PET tracer development, with particular focus on efforts to assess disease-related PDE pathophysiology and support drug discovery. With regard to PDE isoforms that have not yet been elucidated for PET imaging, we mainly discuss recent developments of respective isoform-selective therapeutics.

    Overview of the Phosphodiesterase (PDE) Superfamily

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    To date, 11 PDE families have been identified based on the homology of their C-terminal catalytic domain (Figure 1). Further, 21 isoforms comprising more than 100 splice variants were grouped according to their N-terminal regulatory domains. These PDEs are different in their 3D structure, kinetic properties, functions, and cellular expression.(1,5,7,11) According to their substrate preference for either cAMP or cGMP, PDEs are subdivided into three groups: cAMP-specific PDEs 4, 7, and 8; cGMP-specific PDEs 5, 6, and 9; and dual-specific PDEs 1â3, 10, and 11, which hydrolyze both cAMP and cGMP. Because the concentration of cAMP or cGMP gives feedback on the activity of PDEs, some dual-specific PDEs are considered to be key players in the crosstalk between cAMP and cGMP. The N-terminal regulatory region of each PDE contains unique structural determinants, directing individual PDEs to different subcellular locations and signalosomes and further allowing them to specifically respond to different post-translational modifications, regulatory molecules, and signals.(1,11,13)
    Most cells harbor several PDE isoforms, though, in different concentrations, proportions, and subcellular locations. Although PDEs are widely expressed in the CNS and peripheral tissues, specific PDE isoform expression can vary according to cell type and localization, thereby allowing a remarkable functional diversity (Scheme 1, Table 1).(1,13,23)
    Table 1. Cyclic Nucleotide Phosphodiesterase Isozyme Families: Expression and Representative Physiological Functions
    PDE isoformsExpressionPhysiological functions
    PDE1(A, B, C)High expression in the brain, heart, smooth muscles, and lungs.PDE1A plays an important role in regulating the contraction of vascular smooth muscle cells and in sperm function, while PDE1B is involved in dopaminergic signaling, as well as the activation and survival of immune cells. The proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells requires the participation of PDE1C, which has further been linked to neuronal signaling and sperm function.
    PDE2(A)High expression in the brain, heart (myocytes), liver, adrenal cortex, endothelium, and platelets.PDE2A plays a key role in the crosstalk between cGMP and cAMP pathways. Further, it regulates cGMP concentration in neurons, aldosterone secretion from the adrenal gland, and cAMP- and PKA-mediated phosphorylation of Ca2+ channels in the heart. PDE2A exerts a barrier function of endothelial cells under inflammatory conditions.
    PDE3(A, B)High expression in the heart, vascular smooth muscles, and platelets, as well as in the liver, adipose tissues, pancreatic Î²-cells, epithelium, and oocytes.PDE3A regulates cardiac contractility, vascular smooth muscle contraction, platelet aggregation, oocyte maturation, and renin release, while PDE3B promotes insulin signaling and its antilipolytic effects, as well as the inhibitory effects of leptin and other signals on insulin secretion and renin release. Moreover, PDE3B regulates cell cycle/proliferation.
    PDE4(A, B, C, D)Expressed in the brain, heart, kidney, liver, lung, smooth muscle, endothelial cells, immunocytes, and Sertoli cells.Brain function, monocyte and macrophage activation, neutrophil infiltration, vascular smooth muscle proliferation, fertility, vasodilation, and cardiac contractility require the participation of PDE4s.
    PDE5(A)Mainly expressed in the lungs, heart, and cerebellum, but can also be found in smooth and skeletal muscles, kidneys, and platelets.The functions of PDE5A in vascular smooth muscle contraction have been well studied, especially in the male reproductive system and the lung. The regulation of nitric oxide (NO)-cGMP signaling pathways in the brain and platelets, however, are yet to be elucidated.
    PDE6(A, B, C)Highly expressed in the retina and pineal gland.PDE6 plays a unique role of signal transduction in photoreceptors and regulates melatonin release from the pineal gland.
    PDE7(A, B)Predominantly found in the brain, heart, liver, skeletal muscles, kidneys, testes, and pancreas.The function of PDE7 is studied in immune system- and CNS-related pathologies, as well as in some specific cancers, for example, chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
    PDE8(A, B)Primarily expressed in the brain, liver, kidneys, colon, testes, ovary, spleen, and thyroid.PDE8 plays a role in T-cell activation, sperm, or Leydig cell function.
    PDE9(A)Widely expressed in the brain, kidneys, spleen, prostate, and various gastrointestinal tissues.PDE9A has been hypothesized to regulate NO-cGMP signaling in the brain; however, this hypothesis is yet to be corroborated.
    PDE10(A)Enriched in the brain and testes, followed by heart, muscles, and thyroid.PDE10A inhibition can regulate the signaling mediated by dopamine D1 receptor (D1R) and dopamine D2 receptor (D2R). Therefore, the therapeutic potentials in neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as Huntingtonâs disease (HD), Parkinsonâs disease (PD), and schizophrenia have drawn medicinal chemistsâ attention.
    PDE11(A)Highly expressed in skeletal muscles, pituitary and salivary glands, liver, kidneys, testes, prostate, and thyroid.Studies have indicated that PDE11A plays a role in sperm development and function.
    In summary, these findings indicate that PDE isoforms have different functions to modulate distinct signaling pathways in the cell. This offers opportunities for selective targeting of specific PDE isoforms, while sparing othersâa concept that has the potential to yield therapeutics with an optimal riskâbenefit profile.(1,5,12) Further, PDE isoform-selective targeting with PET probes will advance our knowledge on the distinct functions of these isoforms and may ultimately lead to the discovery of novel disease biomarkers.

    cAMP-Specific PDEs

    PDE4âOverview: Subtypes and Distribution

    Phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE4) can specifically hydrolyze cAMP, an important secondary messenger for transducing external stimuli to intracellular chemical signals. PDE4 constitutes four subtypes (A, B, C, and D). The N-terminal region of every isoform is unique, containing the targeting domain (TD) and some upstream conserved regions (UCR1 and UCR2). The UCRs undergo phosphorylation by protein kinase A (PKA) and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK). Of note, the highly conserved catalytic domain of all PDE4 isoforms is located at the C-terminal domain, which is linked to the N-terminal domain by the linker regions 1 and 2 (LR1 and LR2). As shown in Figure 2, PDE4 isoforms can be categorized into long, short, supershort, and dead-short (not shown) enzymesâaccording to the presence and size of UCR1 and UCR2.(24)
    Therapeutic Potential
    PDE4 is widely expressed in the CNS and peripheral organs, where it plays important roles in a variety of pathophysiological processes, including inflammation, cancer, cardiovascular function, CNS function, and metabolic processes.(1,24) Interestingly, some PDE4 isoforms, especially PDE4A, PDE4B, and PDE4D, play a major role in the hydrolysis of cAMP in most immune and inflammatory cells, including T cells, B cells, eosinophils, neutrophils, dendritic cells, monocytes, and macrophages. Accordingly, anti-inflammatory processes are mediated by PKA and/or exchange protein directly activated by cAMP (EPAC), following elevated cAMP levels through PDE4 inhibition. These molecular processes can result in activation, proliferation, and release of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin (IL)-1, IL-12, and IL-18, tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-Î±), and interferon gamma (IFNÎ³).(25,26) In an animal model of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), enhanced intracellular cAMP levels, triggered by inhibition of PDE4, decreased cerebrovascular endothelial permeability and diminished transendothelial transport of inflammatory mediators. On one hand, inhibition of PDE4 can decrease T cell proliferation and reduce the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-a and IL-17). On the other hand, it can stimulate the release of anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10 in EAE mice.(8)
    In the CNS, the regulation of intracellular cAMP levels by PDE4-mediated hydrolysis is a crucial mechanism to control downstream signaling. For instance, sufficient levels of cAMP are required for the activation of PKA and the subsequent phosphorylation of cAMP-response element binding protein (CREB), which contributes to a healthy memory function. In the corticostriatal network, signal transduction is mediated by cAMP/PKA signaling pathways. Accordingly, inhibition of PDE4 led to a cAMP/PKA/CREB-mediated enhancement of neuroplasticity.(27,28) Given that PDE4 inhibition had proven effective for enhanced neuronal plasticity and anti-neuroinflammatory response in various animal models, including schizophrenia, Alzheimerâs disease (AD), multiple sclerosis (MS), and acute brain injury (ABI), recent studies have increasingly focused on exploiting PDE4 inhibition in the CNS.
    PDE4 activity is an important regulator of intracellular cAMP concentration, which, in turn, controls PKA-mediated phosphorylation of specific proteins, thereby regulating cardiac signaling by signalosomes in cardiomyocytes (Figure 3). Notably, when cGMP levels are low in vascular endothelial cells (VECs), PDE4 activity plays a major role in activating PKA and EPAC.(24) Importantly, PDE4D and EPAC have been identified as key mediators in the regulation of the vascular permeability through pharmacological inhibition and siRNA-mediated knockdown.(29) PDE4 is widely expressed and dominates the cAMP-hydrolysis in most human tumor cell lines. In these malignant cells, PDE4-cAMP-PKA/EPAC signaling pathways are involved in cell differentiation, proliferation, and apoptosis.(10,29) In some animal models, PDE4 inhibitors such as roflumilast and exisulind have shown positive effects for the treatment of lung cancer, bladder cancer, chronic lymphatic leukemia, and colorectal cancer.(10)
    Drug Discovery
    As previously mentioned, PDE4 inhibitors (shown in Figure 4) have shown positive therapeutic effects for animal models of various diseases. As of today, five drugs have been approved by the FDA. For instance, the PDE4-selective inhibitor roflumilast has been approved for the treatment of severe COPD and COPD exacerbations. Roflumilast attenuates COPD-related inflammation through multiple mechanisms, namely, the reduction of inflammatory mediators, the expression of cell surface markers and the inhibition of apoptosis. Data obtained from clinical trials suggest that roflumilast is most beneficial to patients with severe COPD and can reduce moderate to severe exacerbations.(30) In addition, new clinical trials for several indications, including polycystic ovary syndrome, cognitive deficits in schizophrenia, cognition (dementia), insulin and blood sugar levels in prediabetic overweight and obese individuals, asthma, bronchiectasis, and lymphoma, are in progress. In 2014, oral apremilast, a PDE4 inhibitor, was approved by the FDA for the treatment of psoriasis. New clinical indications of apremilast for other inflammatory skin diseases, Behcet syndrome, and alcoholism are being explored.(1) Through a mechanism similar to that for apremilast, crisaborole ointment was approved for the treatment of mild to moderate atopic dermatitis in patients >2 years of age.(31) Drotaverine is a PDE4-selective inhibitor and structurally related to papaverine. Although approved for the treatment of functional bowel disorders and pain, caused by smooth muscle spasm in some countries, drotaverine was reported to elicit fainting, nausea, vomiting, seizures, and cardiac toxicity.(1) In contrast to drotaverine, ibudilast is a nonselective allosteric PDE inhibitor with an IC50 â¤ 10 Î¼M for human PDE 3, 4, 10, and 11. Anti-inflammatory activity of ibudilast in the peripheral immune system and in the CNS can play protective roles in the treatment of asthma, COPD, multiple sclerosis, chronic neuropathic pain, and opioid dependence. Thus, various forms of ibudilast have been approved as anti-inflammatory drugs for asthma and allergic conjunctivitis in Asian countries. Further, ibudilast is the medication of choice for the treatment of dizziness related to cerebral infarction.(32)
    Dual PDE 3 and 4 inhibitor RPL554 has shown anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting PDE4 and is currently used for the treatment of respiratory diseases, such as COPD and asthma, despite exhibiting an IC50 for PDE3 that is more than 3000 times that for PDE4.(33) PDE4 inhibitors have been shown to be effective against neurological disorders and psychiatric diseases in various preclinical studies; however, none is approved for the treatment of these conditions. In a preclinical study, the brain-penetrant PDE4-selective inhibitor, GSK356278, improved anxiety and enhanced cognition without inducing major side effects.(34) Recently, the clinical phase I study (NCT01573819) of GSK356278, which is for the treatment of HD, depressive disorder, and anxiety disorders has been completed. In Phase II clinical trials, treatment with HT-0712 was evaluated for age-associated memory impairment (AAMI), because HT-0712 was found to enhance long-term memory formation and to reduce age-associated memory impairment in aged mice.(34)
    PDE4 inhibitors can induce serious side effects. Notably, distinct PDE4 isoforms have a highly conserved sequence and share a high degree of structural homology in the catalytic domains. Consequently, the development of isoform-selective PDE4 inhibitors is highly challenging. BPN14770 is a PDE4D-selective negative allosteric modulator with binding affinity values (IC50) of 7.8 nM and 7.4 nM for PDE4D7 and PDE4D3, respectively. BPN14770 was found to bind to a primate-specific N-terminal region, thereby inhibiting the PDE4-mediated degradation of cAMP. As such, BPN14770 blocked the amnesic effects of scopolamine, increased cAMP signaling in the brain, and increased brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) as well as markers of neuronal plasticity associated with memory.(35,36) The enhancing effects on memory make BPN14770 a promising PDE4D-selective drug in clinical trials Phase II for the treatment of AD and fragile X syndrome.
    PET Ligands
    Although studies of rolipram for the treatment of depression were terminated in the early 1990s due to the significant gastrointestinal side effects, rolipram is still used for research purposes and served as a lead molecule in drug discovery. Indeed, research on PET radioligands targeting the PDE superfamily (shown in Figure 4) started with [11C]rolipram. In 1997, Dasilva et al. first reported on 11C labeled racemic rolipram and Ro 20â1724 as potential radioligands for imaging PDE4.(37) In subsequent studies, [11C]Rolipram was found to exert higher selectivity for PDE4 than [11C]Ro 20â1724.(38) Notably, (R)-[11C]rolipram displayed enhanced brain uptake and selectivity toward PDE4 than racemic [11C]rolipram and (S)-[11C]rolipram. In addition, given that (S)-[11C]rolipram was rapidly metabolized in vivo, (R)-[11C]rolipram was considered to be more suitable than (S)-[11C]-rolipram for PET imaging.(39)
    Evaluations using PET imaging in rats, pigs, monkeys, and humans revealed a heterogeneous and region-specific distribution of (R)-[11C]rolipram in the brain as well as the heart. PET studies in animal models of aging, obesity, diabetic cardiomyopathy, heart failure, adriamycin-induced cardiotoxicity, and myocardial infarction demonstrated that (R)-[11C]rolipram can be used to monitor PDE4 levels and impaired cAMP signaling.(40â43) For example, (R)-[11C]rolipram was used to image PDE4 after treatments with drugs affecting cAMP levels. These imaging studies revealed changes in PDE4 levels and provided insight into understanding disease states with altered concentrations of synaptic noradrenaline (NA), serotonin (5-HT), and histamine (HA).(40,41) Additional research efforts provided a more comprehensive quantitative analysis of (R)-[11C]rolipram, accounting for data accuracy and reproducibility. As such, the level of radiotracer in the rat and canine heart was quantified using Logan analysis and models comprising one or two tissue-compartment models.(44,45) In 2002, the first case of PET imaging using (R)-[11C]rolipram in the living human brain was reported.(43) This initial study was followed by a series of clinical trials using (R)-[11C]rolipram both in healthy people (NCT01215552, NCT00250172) and in patients with CNS diseases, including HD (NCT01602900), MDD (NCT00369798), and McCune-Albright Syndrome (MAS, NCT02743377). (R)-[11C]rolipram PET showed an in vivo downregulation of brain PDE4 levels in MDD patients not receiving antidepressant therapy and supported the concept that a downregulation of the cAMP cascade, including adenylyl cyclases (ACs), cAMP-dependent PKA, CREB, and BDNF, is indeed involved in the pathology of MDD.(46) Due to the reversible binding of (R)-[11C]rolipram to PDE4, compartmental modeling was applicable to calculate VT/fP (total distribution volume/plasma free fraction) and to offset the effect of cerebral blood flow. Quantitative data of rolipram binding in certain brain regions displayed similar declines, ranging from 20% (frontal cortex and caudate) to 24% (cerebellum), with an average decrease of 22%. However, it was not possible to reliably assess disease severity by (R)-[11C]rolipram PET.(46)
    Derivatization of rolipram led to the discovery of MNI-617, a PDE4 inhibitor with a 5-fold increased affinity for PDE4 (Kd = 0.26 nM), as compared to R-(â)-rolipram (Kd = 1.6 nM). The deutero-analogue d2-[18F]MNI-617 was selected for in vivo evaluation, because the substitution of [18F]fluoromethyl by [18F]fluoromethyl-d2 was envisioned to increase metabolic stability and reduce enzyme-mediated defluorination, as previously shown for other probes.(9,10) PET studies in rhesus monkeys revealed that the radioligand can penetrate the blood brain barrier (BBB), while exhibiting a distribution pattern that is consistent with previously reported PDE4 expression levels. Nonetheless, a rapid in vivo metabolism (<5% of intact parent radioligand in the plasma at 15 min post-injection) and significant accumulation of radioactivity in the skull, despite a deuterium-bearing fluoroethyl side chain, limited the application of d2-[18F]MNI-617 for PDE4-targeted PET.(47)
    Improving PET tracer selectivity among PDE4 subtypes is critical for successful tracer application. In 2017, Zhang et al. reported on the development of a PDE4B-preferring PET radioligand, codenamed [18F]PF-06445974. In the early stage of compound screening, Bmax and brain biodistribution were used to define the required potency range and selectivity index. Following an initial SAR analysis and specificity assessment, promising ligands were used for PET studies. Under baseline conditions, PET studies in cynomolgus monkeys revealed that [18F]PF-06445974 reached a peak whole brain standard uptake values (SUVs) of â¼3 at 30 min post-injection. By quantitative PET measurements of tissue volume of distribution (VT), a target occupancy of â¼92% was estimated after pretreatment with a structurally distinct PDE4B inhibitor (0.5 mg/kg, subcutaneous injection) 4 h prior to the tracer injection. In all, [18F]PF-06445974 serves as a promising lead scaffold for the further development of PDE4B-selective radioligands for PET imaging.(48)
    PDE4D was found to be implicated in cognitive function and depression. Recently, four PET radioligands were labeled with 11C for imaging PDE4D in the brain after a comprehensive compound screening, that accounted for inhibitory potency, selectivity, compound lipophilicity, and brain uptake. The most promising two probes, [11C]T1660 and [11C]T1650, showed high brain uptake (peak SUV of 3.52 and 3.28, respectively) and specific binding to PDE4D in the monkey CNS. Upon pretreatment with rolipram or BPN14770 (selective PDE4D inhibitor), highest specific binding of [11C]T1660 or [11C]T1650 was found in prefrontal cortex, temporal cortex, and hippocampus. Notably, [11C]T1650 was further advanced to a first-in-man PET study. Although high radioactivity uptake in the human brain was observed, brain VT increased with scan duration, suggesting the accumulation of brain radiometabolites. Indeed, the high radiometabolite fraction detected in the plasma further supported the notion of accumulating brain radiometabolites, although a blocking effect was found in the hippocampus and amygdala. In conclusion, these findings imply that PDE4D-targeted PET in the nonhuman primate brain is feasible; however, radioligands with improved stability are required.(49)
    Recently, 11C-labeled sEH/PDE4 dual inhibitors have been synthesized for PET imaging of neuroinflammation. In particular, MPPA (N-(4-methoxy-2-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl)-1-propionylpiperidine-4-carboxamide) displayed good efficacy by in vitro assays with IC50 values of 2.1 nM (hsEH) and 8.1 nM (PDE4); however, in vivo performance characteristics of [11C]MPPA are yet to be reported.(50)

    PDE7âOverview: Subtypes and Distribution

    The mammalian cAMP PDE7 family is endowed with two subtypes, namely, PDE7A and PDE7B. While PDE7A consists of three splice variants, PDE7A1â3, in human, and two splice variants in rodents, a single PDE7B variant is known in humans and mice. In contrast, three PDE7B splice variants have been identified so far in rats.(1) PDE7 isoenzymes have distinct distribution patterns among different species. As such, human and mouse PDE7B and PDE7A1, along with rat PDE7A2, are mainly located in the brain, while human and mouse PDE7A1 are predominantly expressed in immune cells. Generally speaking, PDE7 subtypes can be found in the mammalian heart, liver, skeletal muscles, kidneys, ovaries, testes, and pancreas.(12,51,52) It is worth noting, however, that no regulatory domain has been identified in the N-terminal region of PDE7 to date.(12)
    Therapeutic Potentials
    The therapeutic potential of targeting PDE7 encompasses immune-related, cardiovascular, reproductive, bone and muscle diseases, as well as CNS disorders and various cancer types. A growing body of evidence demonstrated that PDE7 is implicated in pro-inflammatory processes and plays a key role in T-cell activation/proliferation via regulation of cAMP.(51,53) Attributed to their anti-inflammatory effect, PDE7 inhibitors may have the potential to outperform PDE4 inhibitors for the treatment of respiratory diseases in order to reduce typical side effects, such as nausea and vomiting. Similarly, PDE7 inhibition has recently emerged as a good therapeutic option for the treatment of different CNS disorders. As such, studies suggest that the inhibition of PDE7 may provide neuroprotection and be beneficial to treat impaired cognition, neuroinflammation, and depression. Therapeutic benefit from PDE7 inhibitors has been observed in animal models of neurological and inflammatory disorders, including Parkinsonâs disease (PD), AD, stroke, MS, and LPS-induced autoimmune encephalomyelitis.(54,55) Of note, PDE7 has further been suggested as a pharmacological target in oncology. As such, PDE7 has been linked to chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), mantle cell lymphoma (MCL), and endometrial cancer (EC). Compared to the PDE7B expression in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from healthy volunteers, PDE7B expression was found to be substantially increased (more than 20-fold) in both CLL and MCL patientsâ PBMCs.(52,56,57) Furthermore, PDE7A was found to promote endometrial cancer cell migration and invasion by downregulation of the miR-1/133a cluster.(58)
    Drug Discovery
    Due to the high degree of sequence homology (32% in the catalytic domain and 72% in the active site) between PDE7 and PDE4, most PDE7 inhibitors exert pharmacological activity on PDE4. Therefore, the development of PDE7 selective inhibitors is considered challenging. Nonetheless, there are some promising therapeutic agents, and this section will provide selected examples of PDE7-targeted drug development.
    BRL-50481 is a PDE7A1 selective inhibitor with an IC50 of 0.26 Î¼M and selectivity over PDE1B, PDE1C, PDE2, PDE3, PDE5, and PDE4A4 (IC50 = 62 Î¼M). Notably, BRL-50481 was first used as an in vitro tool in human pro-inflammatory cells. Notwithstanding the modest inhibitory effect on human monocytes, lung macrophages, and CD8+ T-lymphocytes upon stand-alone BRL-50481 treatment, BRL-50481 significantly enhanced the effects of other cAMP-elevating drugs, especially when PDE7A1 was up-regulated.(59) Similarly, a study with BRL-50481, TC3.6, S14, and VP1.15 indicated that the latter two enhanced oligodendrocyte precursor (OPC) survival and differentiation during brain development and in adulthood. Of note, PDE7 may act as a therapeutic remyelination agent for the treatment of MS.(53) In a follow-up study, TC3.6 and VP1.15 have been demonstrated to possess potent neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory effects in other neurological disorders, including AD, PD, spinal cord injury, and MS.(58,60) ASB16165, exhibiting an IC50 value of 15 nM for human PDE7A, suppressed IL-12-induced IFN-Î³ production by T lymphoblasts and the induction of activated CD4+/CD8+ T cells. These findings indicated that ASB16165 may be beneficial for the treatment of immunological disorders.(61) In particular, ASB16165 was successfully used to treat TNF-Î±-mediated skin inflammation in a mouse model of TPA-induced dermatitis.(62)
    In the past two decades, a series of heterocyclic small molecules, including benzo-thienothiadiazine dioxides,(63) pyrimidines,(64) thiadiazoles,(65) spiroquinazolinones,(66) sulfides,(67) thieno[3,2-d]pyrimidinones,(68) quinazolinones, and quinazolinethiones,(69) were studied as potent and selective PDE7 inhibitors. A summary of selected PDE7 inhibitors is depicted in Figure 5.
    PET Ligands
    To date, only a few clinical studies on PDE7 ligands have been reported, although several PDE7 selective inhibitors have been validated in animal models. Of note, the development of PDE7 selective PET radioligands is of paramount value to understand the role of PDE7 in various disease pathologies and guide drug discovery efforts. Compared to the diversity of therapeutic agents, radioligand development for PDE7 is lagging behind, with only a few reported examples. As such, [18F]MICA-003 (PDE7 IC50 = 17.0 nM) and [11C]MICA-005 (PDE7 IC50 = 1.7 nM), which are based on a spiroquinazolinone scaffold, were evaluated as PDE7 PET radioligands in the mammalian brain.(70) Both radioligands were able to penetrate the BBB rapidly and possessed good in vivo stability in the brainâwith â¼84% of intact [11C]MICA-005 and â¼74% of intact [18F]MICA-003, respectively, at 15 min post-injection. Nevertheless, they displayed a homogeneous distribution across the brain, which is not in accordance with known target expression patterns. Further, a fast tracer washout from the brain was observed in PET imaging studies. Consequently, [18F]MICA-003 and [11C]MICA-005 were not suitable for PDE7 quantification in the brain.
    Recently, a triazolo-pyrazine derivative, code-named [11C]MTP38, was developed as PDE7-targeted PET radioligand. The synthesis of [11C]MTP38 was achieved from a bromo precursor using [11C]HCN.(71) Initial autoradiograms and PET scans of rat and rhesus monkey brains showed a higher tracer uptake in the striatum, as compared to the cerebellum. However, a relatively fast washout of [11C]MTP38 from the rat and monkey brains ultimately resulted in a moderate in vivo specificity in preclinical studies.(71) Nevertheless, [11C]MTP38 is the first PDE7 PET ligand tested in human subjects,(72) and further experiments are warranted to elucidate the suitability of [11C]MTP38 not only for subtype-selective PDE imaging, but also for studying target engagement in humans.
    In light of the various PDE7-related pathologies, the development of PDE7 selective PET radioligands can help to better define underlying disease mechanisms, thereby providing crucial information for clinical drug discovery.

    PDE8âOverview: Subtypes, Distribution, and Characteristics

    The cAMP PDE8 family is subdivided into PDE8A and PDE8B. While PDE8A is highly expressed in the testis and T-cells, PDE8B is mainly found in the brain and thyroid. PDE8 exhibits a higher affinity and lower Km (â 0.04â0.15 Î¼M) for cAMP, as compared to other PDE isoforms. Moreover, phosphorylation of PDE8 by PKA triggers its catalytic activity, rendering PDE8 a potential target to control intracellular cAMP levels.(6)
    Therapeutic Potentials
    A growing body of evidence suggests that the assembly of PDE8 and Raf-1 may be a novel mechanism to target tumor cells, in which case the Ras/Raf/MEK/ERK pathway plays a critical role in malignant transformation.(10,11) Further, the upregulation of both mRNA and protein expression of PDE8A on activated CD4(+) T cells suggests that PDE8-based therapeutics may potentially act as immunomodulators. Notably, studies in PDE8B knockout mice indicated that inhibition of PDE8B can improve cognitive and motor functions.(73) Moreover, it has been reported that PDE8 plays a vital role in Ca2+ transport in ventricular myocytes, thyroid dysfunction, sperm, and Leydig cell function, as well as T3 and T4 production.(6)
    Drug Discovery
    To date, most of the available PDE8 inhibitors are nonselective (e.g., dipyridamole and BC8â15). One of the few exceptions, PF-04957325, was developed by Pfizer and is a widely used PDE8-selective inhibitor with a nanomolar IC50 value (0.7 nM for PDE8A, 0.3 nM for PDE8B, Figure 6). In a model of T-cell adhesion, the PF-04957325-induced suppression for T-cell adhesion to endothelial cells occurred during extravasation.(10) These results imply that PDE8 inhibitors can be effective for the treatment of T-cell lymphomas. Currently, there is no example of PDE8 PET radioligands.

    cGMP-Specific PDEs

    Several PDEs can degrade cGMP, which is synthesized from GTP by two guanylyl cyclases (GCs), namely, the soluble and particulate GCs. This degradation process serves to regulate the intracellular concentration of cGMP at specific subcellular compartments. Not only does cGMP activate cyclic nucleotide-gated channels (CNGs), but it also stimulates cGMP-dependent protein kinases (PKGs). Indeed, signaling via the cGMP pathway can promote phosphorylation of a large number of downstream targets. Three PDEs, specifically, PDE5, 6, and 9, were found to be merely allosterically modulated by cGMP.(1,74) In comparison to PDE6 and PDE9, PDE5 has been relatively well studied in several pathologies, and as such, several PDE5-selective inhibitors and PET probes have been developed. In this section, the pharmacological effects of PDE5 inhibitors and the development of PET radioligands will be emphasized by examples in several disease models. Further, a brief introduction to PDE6- and PDE9-targeted drug development will be provided.

    PDE5âStructural Overview

    The N-terminus of PDE5 is endowed with a phosphorylation site, two allosteric cGMP-binding sites (GAF domains), and at least parts of the dimerization domain. In contrast, the C-terminus bears the catalytic domain, encompassing two zinc-binding motifs and a catalytic cGMP-binding site.(75)
    Therapeutic Potentials
    PDE5 inhibitors, such as sildenafil and vardenafil, were first widely applied as treatments for erectile dysfunction (ED). With the assessment of their efficacy and safety as well as the understanding of the cGMP-mediated regulatory mechanisms, the application in nonreproductive diseases has triggered scientific interest. Accordingly, extensive and diverse preclinical and clinical trials have been performed in recent years, and concurrent PDE5 inhibitors have proven their efficacy for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Indeed, two PDE5 inhibitors have been FDA approved for the treatment of PAH. Importantly, accumulating data indicates that PDE5 inhibitors may be useful to treat several diseases such as coronary artery disease, AD, PD, stroke, and solid tumors. A summary of the various implications of PDE5, stratified by disease area, is provided in Figure 7.
    The role of PDE5 is to degrade cGMP to 5â²-GMP. PDE5 inhibition precludes the degradation of cGMP, thus resulting in an upregulation of intracellular cGMP, which enhances the NO/cGMP/PKG signaling pathway and its downstream signal transmission, causing a series of physiological and pathological effects. In the following section, we will introduce the molecular mechanisms by which PDE5 inhibitors contribute to smooth muscle relaxation, cardiovascular protection, and neuroprotection (Figure 8). Upon stimulation, endothelial cells release NO, which can diffuse into smooth muscle cells and activate sGCs. sGCs are required to catalyze the generation of cGMP from GTP. Notably, PDE5 inhibitors can block the hydrolysis of cGMP to increase the intracellular concentration of cGMP, which activates PKGs and regulates CNGs. The actions of myosin phosphatases, as well as the phosphorylation of inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) receptor and other substrates, ultimately result in smooth muscle relaxation.(75,76)
    Several studies on heart injury have concluded that PDE5 inhibitors can play a role in myocardial protection. Although there is ongoing controversy about the downstream mechanism of the NO/cGMP/PKG signaling pathway, it has been shown that the upregulation of cGMP by PDE5 inhibitors may enhance PKG activation, subsequently leading to mitochondrial KATP (MitoKATP) channel opening. In mitochondria, opening the MitoKATP channel is beneficial to partially compensate the membrane potential, and results in a normal H+ electrochemical gradient for ATP synthesis. Further, the latter maintains a healthy Ca2+ homeostasis, which is crucial to cell survival and exerts cardioprotection.(77)
    Recently, applications of PDE5 inhibitors in neurological diseases have been growing fast, particularly in neuroinflammatory and neurodegenerative diseases, due to their protective effects on synaptic plasticity and memory function. The detailed mechanism of action of PDE5 inhibitors in the nervous system has been reviewed elsewhere.(74,78) In general, the signaling pathways of NO/cGMP/PKG play an essential role in the treatment of several neurological diseases, such as AD, PD, neuropathic pain, and MS.
    Drug Discovery and PET Ligands
    In 1998, sildenafil was the first PDE5 inhibitor to be approved by the FDA and EMA. Subsequently, a series of PDE5 inhibitors, including vardenafil, tadalafil, avanafil, udenafil, and mirodenafil, have been approved for the treatment of ED. In addition, some PDE5 inhibitors have been developed for new indications, including PAH and benign prostatic hyperplasia.(1) A summary of reported PDE5 inhibitor drugs and PET radioligands is depicted in Figure 9.
    The first 11C-labeled PDE5 inhibitor, designated [11C]RAl-01, was synthesized by methylation of the phenolic precursor with [11C]CH3I. Whole-body PET imaging in pigs indicated a time-dependent uptake in the liver, as well as accumulation and elimination of radioactivity in the bile. Further, self-blocking studies, in which initial myocardial uptake of [11C]RAL-01 (mean SUV, 3.8 Â± 0.8) was significantly reduced by an excess of nonradioactive RAL-01 (mean SUV = 2.6 Â± 0.4), unveiled that in vivo binding of [11C]RAL-01 is reversible and consistent with the high PDE5 expression in the heart. Of note, however, a low tracer uptake was observed in the lungs, which was unexpected. Given (1) the homogeneous distribution in the brain and (2) that blocking experiments did not result in a statistically significant signal reduction, the use of [11C]RAL-01 for PDE5-targeted PET imaging was discontinued.(79)
    Chekol et al. developed a series of 11C and 18F labeled PDE5A-selective inhibitors (Figure 9, 10â14 and 19â20) based on structureâactivity relationship studies with sildenafil, vardenafil derivates, and avanafil analogues.(80) By ex vivo biodistribution studies of these radioligands in mice, the uptake of [11C]10 ([11C]sildenafil) and [18F]11 in the lung at 30 min p.i. (post injection) was highest among all organs (SUVmax 8.0 Â± 1.9 and 8.9 Â± 0.8, respectively). After pretreatment with tadalafil (commercially available PDE5 inhibitor), a significantly reduced lung uptake of [11C]sildenafil (Figure 9, 10) (>86% reduction in %ID and SUV) was observed, indicating that [11C]10 can specifically bind to PDE5 in the lungs. Nonetheless, other organs, especially the heart, showed no specific tracer binding. The limited uptake in the heart and reproductive system may be attributed to the low expression levels of PDE5 in these organs under physiological conditions. Further, it was shown that [11C]10 crosses the BBB in rodents and nonhuman primates, however, with limited accumulation in the CNS parenchyma.(81) Of note, PET imaging with [11C]10 revealed heterogeneous radiotracer distribution with high accumulation in the liver, kidneys, and bladder. In an early phase after tracer injection, images revealed that the radioactivity was accumulated in the brain. At later imaging time points (4â80 min), whole brain uptake was relatively low (%ID/cm3 < 0.11). Accordingly, [11C]10 was deemed unsuitable for the quantification of PDE5 expression or occupancy in the brain. Further, radiometabolic analysis using blood samples showed that [11C]10 was rapidly washed out and metabolized, which is consistent with autoradiograms of 14C-labeled sildenafil. Ex vivo biodistribution suggested that a fraction of the probe was bound to the blood vasculature and can be displaced with nonlabeled sildenafil. Indeed, displacement studies performed with PET further supported the latter hypothesis.
    Avanafil analogues 15â18 and pyrido[3,4-b]pyrazin-2(1H)-one derivatives 21â22 (Figure 9) were labeled with 11C or 18F to visualize PDE5 in the mammalian brain.(82â86) Two quinoline-based derivatives, compounds 15 and 16, with high inhibitory activities (IC50(PDE5) = 1.86 nM and IC50(PDE5A) = 5.92 nM) were labeled with 18F via a one-step nucleophilic substitution reaction. In vitro autoradiograms of [18F]15 and [18F]16 on mouse tissue sections indicated a tracer binding in the heart and lung, which is in accordance with reported PDE5 expression patterns. The competitive binding studies did not show satisfactory specific PDE5 binding, potentially owing to off-target activity. Unfortunately, the high nonspecific binding was also detected by autoradiographic blocking studies of [18F]15 and [18F]16 on porcine brain slices.(83,86) Given the reported estimations of Bmax values (ca. 0.1 nM) in the mouse cerebrum, probes with subnanomolar binding affinity and improved in vivo stability are presumably necessary to achieve a binding potential suitable for neuroimaging.(87)
    In 2017, [11C]21 and [18F]22, with nanomolar binding affinities toward PDE5 (IC50 6.6 nM and 6.4 nM, respectively), were evaluated by in vitro autoradiography and dynamic PET studies in mice. Notably, ex vivo biodistribution studies in wild-type mice revealed an accumulation of [11C]21 and [18F]22 in major organs including the kidneys, liver, lungs, and intestines at 2 min post-injection. Highest uptake value of [11C]21 and [18F]22 was obtained in the lungs at all studied time points. Blocking experiments with tadalafil pretreatment indicated partial PDE5 binding of [11C]21 and [18F]22 in the lungs (32% and 70% signal reductions, respectively, at 30 min p.i.). Evaluations of two tracers were further performed in transgenic mice, overexpressing cardiomyocyte-specific PDE5 (PDE5 TG). In biodistribution studies, highest PDE5-specific uptake was observed for [11C]21 and [18F]22 in the myocardium of PDE5 TG mice at 30 min post-injection. Compared to the baseline scan, a significant reduction of myocardial tracer uptake of both radioligands (80% for [11C]21 and 87% for [18F]22) was observed after tadalafil pretreatment of PDE5 TG mice. These blocking studies revealed that myocardial retention of [11C]21 and [18F]22 in TG mice was PDE5-specific. Furthermore, PET imaging experiments showed specific and reversible binding of [18F]22 to PDE5 in the myocardium of PDE5 TG mice, as confirmed by the efficient blockade effect with the structurally unrelated PDE5 inhibitor tadalafil in chasing and blocking experiments. Although high brain uptake of [11C]21 and [18F]22 was observed by dynamic microPET in rats, this uptake was found to be independent of PDE5, as self-blocking in vivo did not result in any significant reduction in brain uptake.(82) Finally, 11C-labeled PDE5 PET tracers ([11C]17 and [11C]18) have been developed for myocardial and neuroimaging; however, their preclinical evaluation has not yet been reported.(84,88)
    In conclusion, PDE5-selective PET tracers that have been developed were particularly tailored toward imaging the cardiovascular system, the lungs, or the brain. Among the existing probes, some exhibit suitable performance characteristics, such as high specific uptake and retention, as well as a broad applicability across species. Nonetheless, myocardial- and lung-targeted probes were plagued by rapid in vivo metabolism. Further, although there is an increasing number of PET studies focusing on PDE5 in the brain, no radioligand with considerable in vivo specificity for PDE5 in the CNS has yet been reported. Possible hurdles include the blood-brain barrier and the relatively low PDE5 expression levels in the CNS. Thus, candidate molecules with high binding affinities, high metabolic stability, and the ability to enter the CNS are need for successful PDE5 PET imaging in the CNS.

    PDE6âOverview: Distribution and Function

    Phosphodiesterase 6 (PDE6) is highly expressed in the retina, specifically in the internal membranes of retinal photoreceptors. Unlike other PDEs, it is a central effector enzyme in G protein-coupled visual transduction in vertebrate rod and cone photoreceptors.(89â92)
    In the absence of light, the synthesis of cGMP is reduced by the attenuation of GC activating proteins (GCAPs) via high intracellular Ca2+ (GCAP becomes loaded with Ca2+ and can no longer activate GCs). Under these conditions, cGMP activity is suppressed, which increases the influx of Ca2+ and Na+ via CNGCs and maintains low cGMP levels. In the presence of light, however, photon (hÎ½) absorption induces rhodopsin conformational changes, which triggers the activation of the GTP-binding protein transducin, thereby releasing the inhibitory Î³ subunit from PDE6. Once PDE6 is active, it hydrolyzes cGMP and the decreasing cGMP levels lead to the closure of CNGCs. Since Ca2+ is constantly extruded via Na+/Ca2+/K+ exchanger (NCKX), a reduction of intracellular Ca2+ levels can be observed, allowing Mg2+ to replace Ca2+ at the GCAP binding site, thereby reactivating GCAP and stimulating GC to synthesize new cGMP. This, in turn, leads to reopening of CNGCs and restores photoreceptor sensitivity during light adaptation (Figure 10).(90â94) Consequently, both cGMP and Ca2+ concentrations in the photoreceptor are closely linked by a feedback loop that would normally limit the levels of both second messengers to their physiological ranges.(95)
    cGMP/PKG-dependent cell death in photoreceptors was found in several experiments using mouse models of retinal degeneration (rd). Genetic loss-of-function mutations in PDE6 lead to the upregulation of cGMP. Both activation of CNGCs to elevate the Ca2+ and activation of PKG via increasing cGMP are caused by photoreceptor cell death.(96,97) Accordingly, PDE6 may be a potential biomarker for the diagnosis of retinopathy.
    It is noteworthy that PDE6 is also found to be expressed in breast cancer cell lines and breast cancer patient biopsies, at both mRNA and protein levels.(98) However, further studies are needed to fully elucidate the role of PDE6 in breast cancer.
    Due to the similarity in structure and biological activities, many PDE5 inhibitors also possess inhibitory activity to PDE6. For example, the most extensively studied PDE5 inhibitor, sildenafil, effectively inhibits the activity of rod PDE6 (Ki up to 30 nM). The notion that sildenafil can cause transient visual dysfunction has been underlined in clinical electroretinogram studies.(89) Thus, undesired binding to PDE6 should be avoided in the development of other PDE inhibitors.

    PDE9

    Among the cyclic nucleotide PDE superfamily, PDE9 specifically hydrolyzes cGMP with high efficiency. Structurally, all 21 splice variants are derived from a single PDE9A gene, and there are no GAF domains or other regulatory sequences in the N-terminal region. Human PDE9A has the highest expression levels in Purkinje neurons and the cerebellum, followed by the spleen, intestine, and other sublocations of the brain.(1,13) The reported studies in animal models support the concept that PDE9 inhibitors could improve cognitive function by blocking PDE9 activity in the hippocampus and cortex. Therefore, PDE9 has emerged as a valuable therapeutic target to treat memory impairment in dementia.(12,40â42) Although both BI-409306 and PF-04447943 have been found to be safe and well-tolerated in the clinic, they failed to improve cognitive function in patients or healthy subjects. BI-409306 is currently being tested for the prevention of schizophrenia relapse as well as for the prevention of the first psychotic episode in schizophrenia patients.(99)
    Similar to PDE5, PDE9 was found to play a key role in the regulation of cGMP/PKG signaling pathways in the cardiovascular system. A wealth of studies support that PDE9 inhibitors can be a valid therapeutic target in heart failure, left ventricular hypertrophy, and sickle cell anemia.(4,100,101) Furthermore, PDE9A expression levels in malignant breast tumors are higher than in control tissues.(102) BAY 73â6691 significantly inhibited cell proliferation and induced apoptosis of MCF-7 and MDA-MB468 breast cancer cells in a dose- and time-dependent manner.(10)
    More PDE9 inhibitors with high binding affinity are being developed to combat neurodegenerative disorders, cardiovascular diseases, and various cancer types. A summary of representative inhibitors is provided in Figure 11.(103,104)

    Dual-Specific PDEs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    PDE1âOverview: Subtypes, Distribution, and Therapeutic Potentials

    PDE1 possesses a dual-substrate activity and comprises three family subtypes (PDE1A, PDE1B, and PDE1C) with distinct distributions and various isoforms (Figure 12). The ubiquitous expression of PDE1A in the brain is the lowest out of all three subtypes, while PDE1B shows the highest expression levels in the nucleus accumbens. With regard to the periphery, PDE1A is highly expressed in the kidney and thyroid gland, whereas PDE1C is predominantly expressed in the heart, urinary bladder, and lungs.(23) Among all PDEs, PDE1 is the only enzyme that is stimulated by Ca2+/calmodulin (CaM), thereby resulting in unique cross-talk between Ca2+ and cyclic nucleotides.(105) Owing to the specific distribution of PDE1 in the brain and its characteristic Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent activity, PDE1 inhibitors are generally deemed efficacious in improving the cognitive function in neurodegenerative diseases.

    Drug Discovery

    The most established PDE1 selective inhibitor to date, vinpocetine (IC50(PDE1) = 30 Î¼M), was found to cross the blood-brain barrier, resulting in a favorable outcome in patients suffering from disorders of cerebrovascular origin. Particularly in ischemic post-stroke patients, treatment with vinpocetine showed regional cerebral blood flow redistribution and enhancement of glucose brain supply.(106) In preclinical mice studies, prolonged vinpocetine intake notably resulted in significant improvement of learning and memory.(107) In clinical settings, vinpocetine was investigated in memory impairment (NCT00719953), cerebral infarction (NCT01400035), traumatic brain injury (NCT01515839), epilepsy (NCT02011971, suspended), and inflammation (NCT02878772). Further studies with vinpocetine indicated its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptotic effects,(108) as well as cognitive dysfunction amelioration in AD patients.(109) A highly potent and selective PDE1 inhibitor, ITI-214 (IC50(PDE1) = 0.058 nM, >1000-fold selectivity over other PDEs),(110) enhanced acquisition, consolidation, and retrieval memory processes in rats.(111) Results obtained from studies performed in heart failure disease models of rabbits and dogs suggested that ITI-214 is a potential novel therapeutic agent for patients with heart failure because it can inhibit the activity of PDE1, thereby enhancing cGMP signaling and mediating relaxation of vascular smooth muscles and prompting vasodilation. As such, ITI-214 is being currently assessed in a clinical trial of heart failure (NCT03387215, recruiting)âin addition to its evaluation in schizophrenia (NCT01900522, terminated) and PD (NCT03257046). Given these results, it is not surprising that two ITI-214 structurally related PDE1 inhibitors induced concentration-dependent relaxations and vasodilation in rats, namely, Lu AF58027 (IC50(PDE1) = 13 nM) and Lu AF41228 (IC50(PDE1) = 170 nM).(112,113) Despite the continuous development of novel PDE1 inhibitors, such as the recently reported DNS-0056 (IC50(PDE1) = 26 nM)(114) and PF-04827736 (IC50(PDE1) = 9 nM),(115) no scientific work has been published describing the development of a PDE1 PET tracer. Nonetheless, there is a few examples toward PDE1 tracer development provided as part of a patent application and conference proceedings that show rapid brain uptake.(116â118)

    PDE2âOverview: Distribution and Therapeutic Potentials

    Similar to PDE1, PED2 is a dual substrate-specific phosphodiesterase. However, unlike PED1, it is encoded by the single gene PDE2A with three splice variants (PDE2A1, PDE2A2, and PDE2A3) varying in their N-terminus. Their variability extends to their cellular localization and expression levels. For instance, PDE2A1 is soluble, while PDE2A2 and PDE2A3 are membrane-associated.(119) PDE2A mRNA is more abundant in human brain than peripheral tissues with the highest expression found to be in the caudate, nucleus accumbens, cortex, and hippocampus.(23) These expression levels may justify the potential application of PDE2A inhibitors in memory and cognitive function enhancement.(120) Each PDE2A variant contains GAF-A and GAF-B domains in their respective N-terminus. Binding of the cGMP to GAF-B positively stimulates the hydrolysis of cAMP and reduces aldosterone secretion, which in turn allows PDE2A to orchestrate a âcross-talkâ between cAMP and cGMP signaling cascades.(12,121)

    Drug Discovery

    As shown in Figure 13, various PDE2A inhibitors have been developed and evaluated in preclinical and clinical settings.(120,121) The very first known PDE2A selective inhibitor, adenine derivative EHNA (IC50(PDE2A) = 800 nM), was not suitable for clinical development owing to its limited potency. A follow-up candidate, BAY-60â7550 (IC50(PDE2A) = 4.7 Â± 1 nM), enhanced long-term potentiation of synaptic transmission without altering basal synaptic transmission, and exhibited improved memory effects in rat studies. Further studies in rats revealed that the improvement occurred across different age groups via the enhancement of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) activity in the brain.(122) Subsequent studies with BAY-60â7550 in rats confirmed the improvement of memory consolidation in both early and late phases.(123) Further, treatment with BAY-60â7550 led to the reduction of stress-induced memory impairment by modulating the neuroplasticity-related NMDAR-CaMKII-cGMP/cAMP signaling pathway.(124) Other PDE2A inhibitors such as ND-7001, PF-999 (also termed PF-05180999), and TAK-915 have been evaluated in clinical phase I trials.(120,125) ND-7001 (IC50(PDE2A) = 1 nM)(126,127) was found to be safe and well tolerated with no apparent withdrawal effects.(120) PF-999 (IC50(PDE2A) = 1 nM) was not perceived as safe; its development was discontinued due to safety concerns (NCT01981499). Other trials were either withdrawn (NCT01981486) or the results have not been disclosed (NCT01429740 and NCT01530529). More recently, TAK-915 (IC50(PDE2A) = 0.61 nM)(128) was used for the occupancy study of PDE2A in the brain (NCT02584569) after the evaluation of the safety and tolerability of TAK-915 in healthy volunteers (NCT02461160).

    PET Ligands

    In 2013, [18F]B-23 (IC50(hPDE2A) = 1.4 nM, IC50(rPDE10A) = 14 nM) was found to be a potent PDE2 PET tracer out of â¼200 compounds that were synthesized and evaluated by Janssen Pharmaceutica NV. As such, it was evaluated in biodistribution, radiometabolite analysis, and PET imaging studies.(129) From the results of these experiments, [18F]B-23 showed the highest brain uptake and the slowest washout (2 min-to-30 min ratio = 7.1) in the striatum. Nonetheless, 92% and 82% of intact tracer was detected in the cerebrum and cerebellum, respectively, after 10 min post-injection in rats. The poor metabolic stability halted its further clinical development and utility. Concurrently, a highly selective PDE2 PET tracer, [18F]PF-05270430 (IC50(hPDE2A) = 0.53 nM), was reported by L. Zhang et al.(130) It was developed based on the structureâactivity relationship using PDE2 inhibitor 23 (IC50(PDE2A) = 2.3 nM, >500-fold over other PDEs) as a lead scaffold. PDE2 inhibitor 23 was identified based on PET probe design parameters for physicochemical properties, brain permeability, and nonspecific binding out of 77 radioligands. PET imaging in nonhuman primates showed a rapid and high uptake in the striatum, which could be specifically blocked by the structurally related PDE2A inhibitor PF-999.(131) However, [18F]PF-05270430 displayed low binding potential values that were calculated with the cerebellum as a reference region.(132)
    In 2015, SchrÃ¶der et al. reported two 18F-radiolabeled fluoroalkylated triazine derivatives, [18F]TA3 and [18F]TA4), as potential PET radioligands.(133) Both [18F]TA3 (IC50(hPDE2A) = 11.4 nM, IC50(hPDE10A) = 318 nM) and [18F]TA4 (IC50(hPDE2A) = 7.3 nM, IC50(hPDE10A) = 913 nM) showed specific binding to regions in line with the known PDE2A distribution in rat brain in in vitro autoradiographic studies. Despite these results, the radiometabolites of the two radioligands were found to cross the blood-brain barrier when they were assessed in ex vivo mice metabolite studies, thus impeding their further development.(134) Similarly, [18F]TA5 (IC50(hPDE2A) = 3 nM, IC50(hPDE10A) > 1000 nM), a potent PDE2A ligand belonging to the imidazopyridotriazine structural class, suffered from rapid degradation and the presence of radiomebolites in the mouse brain, thereby rendering [18F]TA5 unsuitable for PET imaging of PDE2A.(135) Contrary to these results, another PDE2A PET radioligand, [18F]BIT1 (IC50(PDE2A) = 3.3 nM, 16-fold over PDE10A), showed appropriate metabolic stability and moderate brain uptake in mice.(136) The drawback of this tracer, however, became apparent in in vitro autoradiographic experiments with pig brain cryosections. Despite showing high tracer accumulation in regions known for their high PDE2A expression, [18F]BIT1 exhibited nonspecific binding in blocking studies with the structurally related PDE2A inhibitor TA1 and BIT1.(137)

    PDE3âOverview: Subtypes, Distribution, and Therapeutic Potentials

    Comparable to the aforementioned PDE1 and PDE2, PDE3 hydrolyzes both cAMP and cGMP with a higher affinity for cGMP than for cAMP. It is transcribed from two genes (PDE3A, PDE3B) that encompass four variants (PDE3A1, PDE3A2, PDE3A3, and PDE3B).(6,12) PDE3 is abundant in the cardiovascular system(6) where PDE3A exhibits the highest expression of all PDEs in the heart. PDE3B, on the other hand, shows the highest expression in the liver.(23) Owing to the diverse localization, these variants orchestrate various physiological responses via unique proteinâprotein interactions.(138) Recently, PDE3 inhibition studies in mice showcased a critical role of PDE3 in basophil and mast cell degranulation, and suggested PDE3 inhibitors as potential therapeutic agents for allergic disease.(139)

    Drug Discovery

    As shown in Figure 14, a number of PDE3 inhibitors have already been approved by the FDA and other health authorities. For instance, cilostazol was FDA-approved in 1999 for intermittent claudication. Amrinone (FDA 1984), milrinone (FDA 1987), enoximone (France 1987), pimobendan (Japan 1994), and olprinone (Japan 1996) were approved for the treatment of congestive heart failure, while anagrelide was approved by the FDA in 1997 for the treatment of thrombocythemeia.(1) Today, numerous clinical trials have been concluded to evaluate the safety, tolerance, efficacy, and other pharmacological properties of these inhibitors. Cilostazol is the most investigated PDE3 inhibitor to date; 137 clinical trials have been registered so far on ClinicalTrial.gov, mainly in Asia (83). These trials explored the therapeutic potential of cilostazol against cerebral infarction, contraception, migraine, tinnitus, and other diseases. Cilostazol was initially considered efficient for the treatment of stroke.(140) Given its improvement of cognitive function by elevating cerebral circulation and AÎ² clearance,(141) cilostazol showed great potency in suppression of cognitive decline in AD patients, though with no substantial effect on dementia.(142) On the molecular level, the beneficial effects could be attributed to the prevention of oxidative damage in the hippocampus(143) and the reduction of AÎ² accumulation and tau phosphorylation through diminishing ApoE-mediated Ab aggregation.(144) Furthermore, a recent study encompassing 9148 participants showed a dose-dependent reduction of dementia emergence rates with cilostazol.(145) The latest studies demonstrated the efficacy of cilostazol in alopecia,(146) Down syndrome,(147) and allergic diseases,(139) rendering cilostazol a multipurpose drug. Meanwhile, olprinone was proven to reduce liver ischemia-reperfusion injury by preventing oxidative stress and activating PKA.(148) It was additionally evaluated as a possible therapy for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).(149)

    PDE10âOverview: Structure and Distribution

    Phosphodiesterase-10 (PDE10) is a dual-substrate specific enzyme that can degrade the intracellular cAMP (Km = 0.05 Î¼M) and cGMP (Km = 3 Î¼M). Both substrates are key second messengers that regulate a number of cellular processes like long-term potentiation, synaptic plasticity, and neurotransmission. PDE10 was found to exhibit a high expression in the CNS (striatum, substantia nigra, and globus pallidus) and a limited distribution in peripheral tissues.(150) Another peculiar characteristic is that PDE10 is the only family of mammalian PDEs that can be activated by cAMP via binding to the GAF domain of PDE10.(151) Two known predominant human isoforms (cytosolic PDE10A1 and membrane-bound PDE10A2) share an almost-identical sequence with the exception of the N-terminal portion of PDE10A2 that bears a putative phosphorylation site by PKA.

    Therapeutic Potentials

    The highest expression level of PDE10A in striatum compared to all other PDEs propose PDE10A inhibitors as a potential therapy for neurodegenerative and neuropsychiatric diseases, such as AD, HD, PD, and schizophrenia. The PKA/PKG-activated downstream proteins in the signaling cascade play significant roles in these diseases. For instance, CREB that is activated by PKA and BDNF modulate neuronal survival and plasticity. Furthermore, BDNF heavily influences striatal growth, and it has been found to exert a pathological increase in post-synaptic signaling in HD.(152) Reports of in vitro studies using highly specific monoclonal antibodies showed that the phosphorylations of tau by PKA created an AD-like state, and led to the dysregulation of subcellular localization of the Î² catalytic subunit of PKA (PKA-CÎ²), the Î²II regulatory subunit of PKA (PKA-RIIÎ²), and the 79 kDa A-kinase-anchoring protein (AKAP79), which are key players in neurofibrillary pathology in AD.(153) EPACs were shown to influence the amyloid precursor protein (APP), a known key protein in AD.(154) Recently, PDE10A was also found to be implicated in other diseases. Specifically, the in vitro decrease of nitrite production, induced by lipopolysaccharide (LPS), indicated the potential of allosteric PDE10A modulators as anti-inflammatory agents.(155) Studies in PDE10A knockout mice validated the PDE10A regulatory role of caloric intake and energy expenditure.(156) PET imaging studies, on the other hand, demonstrated the expression of PDE10A in brown adipose tissues (BAT) in both mice and human. Uncoupling protein 1 (UCP-1) was found reduced in mice treated with the PDE10A inhibitor MP-10 (PF-02545920).(157) Finally, treatment with MP-10 inhibited the Î²-catenin signaling by activating cGMP/PKG signaling pathway. Consequently, the downstream transcription of cellular surviving factors was reduced, resulting in tumor cell growth suppression.(158)
    PDE10A plays a substantial role in neurodegenerative disorders, obesity, inflammatory diseases, and cancer. Due to the high expression of PDE10A in the striatum (Figure 15), clinical investigations were heavily focused on schizophrenia and HD. Contrary to the promising preclinical studies, the clinical outcomes were mostly disappointing.

    Drug Discovery

    In the last two decades, the safe and tolerable inhibitor MP-10 has been the most investigated PDE10 inhibitor. Initial evaluations of MP-10 in schizophrenia were terminated early due to either alarming safety concerns (NCT00570063) or failing to meet the prespecified efficacy criteria (NCT01939548) or poor efficacy (NCT01175135).(159) Clinical trials in the HD population did not fare any better; no significant differences could be detected between MP-10 and placebo (NCT01806896, NCT02197130). Early termination took place during a clinical phase II study assessment that was aiming at investigating the long-term safety, tolerability, and efficacy of MP-10 in HD patients as a result of discouraging findings obtained with study A8241021 (NCT02342548). Other PDE10A inhibitors followed suit when evaluated in schizophrenia and HD patients. For example, evaluation of AMG579 in healthy volunteers and patients was terminated due to business-related reasons (NCT01568203). Another example is TAK-063, which elicited higher incidence of akathisia, dystonia, and extrapyramidal syndromes than the placebo group in phase I (NCT01879722),(160) whereas the phase II study of the same drug failed to reach the designated primary end point (NCT02477020).(161) Another PDE10A inhibitor, OMS643762, was tested in clinical phase II trials, more specifically in HD patients. This trial was, however, terminated by Omeros Corporation (NCT02074410), and evaluation of PBF-999 was similarly terminated due to an amendment in the proposed therapeutic indication (NCT02907294). Despite all the aforementioned results, the clinical interest in these drugs did not wane. There are multiple clinical trials that are still ongoing; MP-10 (NCT00463372), OMS643762 (NCT01952132), EVP-6308 (NCT02037074), RO5545965 (NCT02019329, NCT02824055) in schizophrenia patients, and PBF-999 (NCT02208934) in HD patients. Furthermore, the clinical interest in PDE10A inhibitors is branching toward other diseases, as in the case of the evaluation of PBF-999 in cancer (NCT03786484) and TAK-063 in preventing ketamine-induced brain activity changes (NCT01892189).

    PET Ligands

    Based on the structure of specific PDE10A inhibitor MP-10 (PF-02545920, IC50Â (PDE10A) = 0.18 nM), a number of 11C- and 18F-labeled analogues have been developed for the purpose of PET imaging of PDE10A (Figure 16). In 2011, Tu et al. reported that in vivo PET imaging studies with [11C]MP-10 displayed high selective binding in the striatum of both rat and rhesus monkey brains.(162) Later studies by Plisson et al. unveiled a rapid uptake and wash-out kinetics of [11C]MP-10 in porcine brains, underlining its potential clinical utility.(163) PET imaging with [11C]MP-10 and ex vivo analysis proved that a prior treatment with an anti-psychotic medication (haloperidol, 2 mg/kg/d) in rodents did not alter PDE10A levels in vivo.(164) However, due to the lipophilic nature of a radiolabeled metabolite that was able to cross the BBB, [11C]MP-10 showed reversible kinetics in baboon but irreversible kinetics in rhesus monkeys.(165) To address the radioactive metabolite concern, Fan et al. developed TZ1964B (IC50Â (PDE10A) = 0.40 Â± 0.02 nM) by optimizing the labeling position.(166) This strategy proved to be advantageous; [11C]TZ1964B showed high striatal uptake (1.8 SUV at 30 min p.i.), and no persistently increasing radioactivity in the brain was detected in in vivo PET studies, thereby indicating a superior radiometabolic stability of [11C]TZ1964B.(167) Further PET studies in rodents and nonhuman primates corroborated the earlier results obtained by Fan and co-workers.(168)
    In the same year, Celen et al. reported the 18F-labeled quinoline derivative [18F]JNJ-41510417 (IC50(PDE10A) = 0.5 nM) as a specific and reversible radiotracer for PDE10A with slow brain kinetics.(169) Later, a structurally related derivative, [18F]JNJ-42259152 (IC50(PDE10A) = 2 nM), was developed. It was characterized by a relatively faster brain kinetics and a higher specific to nonspecific binding ratio in rodents and nonhuman primates than [18F]JNJ-41510417.(170,171) Following in vivo studies in a Huntington mouse model, early regional dysfunctions in PDE10A signaling was found in the caudate-putamen and lateral globus pallidus.(172) Although significant reduction of putamen uptake in HD patients (63% decline compared with healthy controls) was observed, no evidence pertaining to a correlation between the loss of PDE10A and disease severity was found.(173) In the presence of cAMP (10 Î¼m), in vitro studies showed a higher binding affinity (Kd = 3.17 Â± 0.91 nM) to PDE10A than without cAMP (Kd = 6.62 Â± 0.7 nM), consistent with the particular role for cAMP to regulate the activity of PDE10A.(174) In a PET imaging study with [18F]JNJ-41510417 in rats that were treated beforehand with d-amphetamine and the D2 antagonist SCH23390, prominent alterations in PDE10A binding were evident. These results suggest a potential interplay between DA neurotransmission and PDE10A expression.(174) However, similar to [11C]MP-10, the radiometabolite obtained from the 2-[18F]fluoroethoxy group has confounded the brain imaging results and, as such, precluded the utility of this radioligand in future studies.(175)
    Papaverine (IC50(PDE10A) = 36 nM) is a natural and potent PDE10A inhibitor that showed rapid brain clearance when it was labeled with carbon-11. Nonetheless, its structure served as the basis for further synthetic modifications such as PQ-10 (IC50(PDE10A) = 16 nM).(176) A radioanalogue of PQ-10, [18F]24, was developed by the Brust group where it showed better brain kinetics compared to [11C]papaverine, alongside an appropriate metabolic stability in mice. However, this radiotracer was plagued by the lack of specific binding properties, as shown by autoradiographic and in vivo blocking studies with MP-10.(177) In 2014, the first report of [18F]MNI-654 (Kd = 0.029 nM) and [18F]MNI-659 (Kd = 0.097 nM) in humans from Oliver and co-workers demonstrated suitable stability (â¼20% of intact parent remained at 120 min p.i. for both tracers) and high uptake in caudate, putamen, and globus pallidus (peak SUV of â¼0.7â1.0 for [18F]MNI-654 and â¼1.5â2.5 for [18F]MNI-659), which is in line with the known PDE10A distribution in the human brain.(178) In view of the favorable kinetics, signal-to-background, and testâretest reliability, [18F]MNI-659 was selected by Russell et al. for imaging premanifest HD (pre-HD), manifest HD (m-HD) (stage 1 and 2), and healthy volunteers (HV).(179) The striatal uptake of [18F]MNI-659 in the HD cohort was noticeably reduced (â48% than HV) and the authors observed a strong inverse correlation between the disease severity and PDE10A tracer uptake, inconsistent with prior studies using [18F]JNJ-42259152.(173) Later, a 15 month longitudinal study showed a sharp reduction in the basal ganglia BPND (nondisplaceable binding potential, about 50% reduction compared to HV). Additionally, annualized rates of decline of [18F]MNI-659 uptake in caudate (16.6%), putamen (6.9%), and globus pallidus (5.8%) in all 8 HD participants, as compared to HV (1% in striatum), were observed, thus highlighting that [18F]MNI-659 is a sensitive and reliable imaging agent for PDE10A imaging.(180) Similarly, an in vivo imaging trial in 40 healthy participants resulted in a 7.8% decline per decade of PDE10A availability in the striatum with regard to age and gender, and a decline to a lesser extent (4.3% per decade) of D2/3 receptor availability in basal ganglia.(181) Given the reduced uptake in striatum in those HD cohorts, in vivo imaging in heterozygous (HET) Q175 mice suggested an MRI-based spatial normalization rather than PET or CT template-based approach would be more favored in order to achieve a better accuracy of BPND quantification.(182) Furthermore, [18F]MNI-659 was the tracer of choice to measure PDE10A distribution in healthy post-mortem brains to acquire further information about its presence and density.(183) Despite the potential utility of [18F]MNI-659 in preclinical and clinical evaluation of HD, the 2-[18F]fluoroethoxy group would be easily metabolized, thereby interfering with the brain PET imaging results. In 2019, [18F]25 was developed by replacing the 2-[18F]fluoroethoxy group with a [18F]fluoromethoxy-d2 moiety. This small modification proved to be critical, leading to better radiometabolic profile and higher BPND values than [18F]MNI-659, as well as placing it at the forefront for future clinical applications.(184)
    Notably, high-throughput screening (HTS) by Merck in 2015 resulted in the identification of [11C]MK-8913 (Ki = 0.15 nM), a structurally related ligand to [18F]MNI-659, out of a quinazolinone series. Blocking studies in rats and monkeys with the PDE10A inhibitor THPP-1 showed the specificity of [11C]MK-8913, and in vivo PET imaging in rats and rhesus monkeys both revealed high striatal uptakes and rapid brain washout. Unexpectedly, a series of 11C labeled THPP-1 analogues showed poor brain uptake in in vivo rhesus monkey studies.(185)In vitro autoradiography with [3H]MK-8913 in human brain tissues similarly showed the highest accumulation in the striatum. Finally, the high selectivity (Ki > 1000 nM for all other PDEs), high Bmax/Kd ratio, moderate lipophilicity (logD = 3.19), favorable radiometabolic profile, and exclusive brain presence of intact tracer suggested that [11C]MK-8913 was a promising PET tracer for further studies.(186)
    In all in vivo experiments comprising mice, rats, nonhuman primates, and healthy volunteers, [11C]Lu AE92686 (IC50(PDE10A) = 0.39 nM) exhibited selective uptake in the striatum with an excellent signal-to-noise ratio. Nonetheless, it suffered from poor metabolic stability in plasma; â¼15% of the intact tracer remained at 40 min p.i. in rats, while 27 Â± 4% of the tracer remained at 30 min p.i. in cynomolgus monkeys.(187) Further, studies in nonhuman primate brains demonstrated the specificity of [11C]Lu AE92686 in the striatum and the potential application for examining PDE10A in the globus pallidus and the substantia nigra.(188) Following PET and MRI studies in schizophrenia patients treated with clozapine, olanzapine, or quetiapine and healthy controls, it was evident that there is a significant correlation between the striatal BPND and cortical thickness in both patients and controls and that the striatal BPND was significantly lower (P = 0.003)(189) in patients. Since no correlation between PDE10A expression and cortical thickness was found within the patient group, further studies in early disease stages of patients with psychotic disorder would be necessary.
    Among seven structurally related candidates for PDE10A radioligands, [11C]T-773 (also known as [11C]KIT-6, IC50(PDE10A) = 0.77 nM) possessing the highest specific binding ratio and fastest washout in human brain was selected for further studies.(190) T-773 was particularly selective for hPDE10A2 with >2500-fold selectivity over other PDEs. Further, in in vitro autoradiography studies with mice, rat, monkey, and human brain sections, [3H]T-773 and [11C]T-773 showed selective accumulation in the striatum of all the tested species.(191) Moreover, lower standardized uptake values and significantly lower BPND were found in both heterozygous and homozygous PDE10A knockout mice compared with wild-type controls by in vivo PET. These findings confirmed the selective binding of [11C]T-773 for PDE10A.(192) Whole body PET imaging in rhesus monkeys (n = 2) showed that the average highest uptake was achieved in the stomach, kidneys, and liver, while excretion was partly via bile and subsequently the gastrointestinal tract besides the urinary tract.(193) Moreover, [11C]T-773 was successfully employed to measure PDE10A occupancy by TAK-063 in the nonhuman primate striatum, although unexpected interactions were found between the uptake of [11C]T-773 and TAK-063 in the cerebellum.(194) Subsequent PET imaging in humans corroborated the prior results of rapid brain penetration and high distribution in the striatum. The results also showed a clear decrease in the cerebellum, as previously observed in rhesus monkeys after the oral administration of TAK-063, suggesting an âoff-targetâ interaction.(195) In 2018, the 18F-labeled analogues, [18F]FM-T-773-d2 and [18F]FE-T-773-d4, were developed where they portrayed favorable kinetics and distribution in the nonhuman primate brains, thereby adding to the growing repertoire of available PDE10A PET probes for clinical applications.(196)
    [11C]AMG 7980 (IC50(PDE10A) = 1.9 nM) showed specific binding in the striatum and globus pallidus in nonhuman primates. The specific striatal uptake was lower than those of [11C]MP-10 and [18F]JNJ-42259152, and analytical HPLC results showed poor metabolic stability in the plasma (24% Â± 15% of the parent compound remained at 70 min p.i.).(197) In the following year, the keto-benzamidazole analogues, AMG 579 (IC50(PDE10A) = 0.18 nM) and [18F]AMG 580 (IC50(PDE10A) = 0.13 nM), were reported by Chen et al. to exhibit superior affinity and potency than [11C]AMG 7980.
